etymology.description: 斷(斷) (duàn, "break"), 捨(捨) (shě, "abandon"), 離(離) (lí, "separate") comes from 斷(斷) which means to "break away," 捨(捨) which involves "abandoning or letting go," and 離(離) which signifies "separation." Together, they form a concept of decluttering by breaking attachment, letting go, and separating oneself from unnecessary material possessions.
etymology.interpretation: 斷捨離(断舍离) (duànshělí) encourages living a simplified life by minimizing material possessions and eliminating unnecessary items, a philosophy aligning with the principles of minimalism. Originally rooted in the Japanese philosophy of 'Danshari,' it has been embraced more broadly in Chinese-speaking contexts.
etymology.simplification: 断舍离 to 斷捨離

examples.chinese: 我决定开始断舍离(我決定開始斷捨離)。
家里太拥挤时(家裏太擁擠時)，断舍离让生活更简约(斷捨離讓生活更簡約)。
examples.pinyin: Jiālǐ tài yōngjǐ shí, duànshělí ràng shēnghuó gèng jiǎnyuē.
examples.english: When home is too crowded, minimalism makes life simpler.
